awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Strain localization, shear zone connectivity, and magma-deformation interactions by depth within a 65 km thick transpressional continental arc
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding how large fault zones develop over time at different depths within the Earth's crust is vital to the goals of assessing earthquake and volcanic hazards and finding natural resources, including natural gas, petroleum, and water. Not only are fault zones the sites of concentrated movement and seismic activity; they also form conduits by which fluids, magmas, and heat circulate through the Earth. A major unsolved problem centers on how the behavior of near surface faults relates to deformation in the deepest parts of fault systems, including the lowermost crust and upper mantle. Two of the most challenging aspects of resolving this problem are (1) a high degree of variability in the physical properties and behavior of faults at great depths and (2) there are few places on Earth that expose large tracts of material that once resided at depths below approximately 40 km and are available for direct study. This project utilizes one of only a few places on the planet where it is possible to directly observe the deep roots of an ancient fault system that once penetrated continental crust to depths of more than 65 km. Deep within Fiordland National Park, in southwest New Zealand, a near vertical fault zone up to 20 km thick can be traced continuously from areas that once resided at depths of 10 km to depths of 65 km during the Cretaceous time period. The research team, in collaboration with New Zealand researchers, will determine the internal structure, mineralogy, and behavior of this ancient fault zone at different depths and will show how the fault zone connects vertically through the crust and helped move, fluids, magmas, and crustal melts from mantle depths to near-surface environments. These are fundamental issues that are important to the understanding of all large fault zones, including those that occur with the United States and elsewhere. The project will also advance desired societal outcomes through an innovative, summer workshop program that provides research experiences to underrepresented students at minority-serving institutions in southern California, thereby promoting interest in research and graduate school opportunities. Providing graduate and undergraduate students with international field experiences and exposure to cutting-edge analytical research facilities will develop a diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce.

An unsolved problem in continental tectonics centers on how competing weakening mechanisms localize deformation into faults and shear zones deep within the roots of continental arcs. This problem is especially acute in Cordilleran systems where episodes of voluminous magmatism, crustal melting, and high-grade metamorphism quickly change the compositional and rheological structures of the deep crust. The aim of this project is to determine how strain localization was achieved and sustained within the deep root of an ancient Cordilleran arc located in Fiordland, New Zealand during a cycle of magmatism and transpression. The project integrates transect maps, U-Pb geo- and thermochronology (zircon, titanite), and electron backscatter diffraction analyses to determine the following: (1) how competing weakening mechanisms localized strain at lower and middle crustal depths with a large transpressional shear zone, (2) how high-strain zones connected vertically across deep crustal boundaries, and (3) how temporal and spatial variations in magmatic, metamorphic, and deformational processes influenced shear zone development. The outcomes of this project will include a new 4-D model that shows how high-strain zones at different depths are physically connected within Cordilleran arcs, how strain localization is achieved and sustained within them, and how the deformation interacts with migrating magma and melts. This project is important because large faults and shear zones play a key role in the formation and evolution of continental lithosphere. They act as agents of weakening and hardening at different depths and they advect mass and heat through the lithosphere. One of the most challenging aspects of studying these features is determining their variability throughout the crust and mantle. Physical experiments, numerical models, and studies of xenoliths help us infer how materials deform at great depths, but polyphase flow laws for lower crustal compositions are scarce and no experimental studies of anorthite-diopside aggregates yet include melt in the deformation. In addition, few places expose large tracts of material that once resided at depths below about 40 km. To address these problems, this project involves a field-based investigation of strain localization mechanisms within the world's largest and deepest (up to 65 km) known exposure of lower arc crust. The project will provide new information on the geometry, composition, thermal evolution, and rheology of lower crustal shear zones that once penetrated the crust to depths of at least 65 km.

The Tectonics Program (Div. of Earth Sciences) and the NSF Office of International Science and Engineering are supporting this project.

por.por_cntn:
The Earth’s continental crust contains an overwhelming majority of its natural resources, and the key to finding and/or predicting the locations of resource concentrations depends on geoscientists’ ability to reconstruct the tectonic history of continental crust generation and movement through geologic time. Continental crust is primarily generated in magmatic arcs above subduction zones, where magma vertically ascends to build continental crust. Faults and their deeper-crustal equivalent, called shear zones, can help channel or impede magma movement, and therefore exert a fundamental control on continental crust distribution. A complicating factor is that faults and shear zones often localize along older crustal discontinuities that strongly influence how faults and shear zones function as conduits of arc magma. In this project, we studied fault and shear zone connectivity and influence on the architecture of continental crust in one of the best exposed sections of arc crust above an ancient subduction zone. We focused on two large, crustal-scale Cretaceous shear zones in Fiordland, New Zealand, and we used interdisciplinary methods including field mapping, macrostructural analysis, geochronology, microstructural analysis, and petrochronology to determine 1) how these shear zones initiated and grew, 2) how older crustal architecture exerted a primary control on the formation of the shear zones, and 3) what role shear zones play in the emplacement of arc magmas and the building of continental crust. 

The primary outcome of our work with respect to intellectual merit is the discovery that microstructural analysis involving electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD) and its derivative crystallographic vorticity axis (CVA) analysis are key methods to determine how shear zones initiate, move, and grow to develop connectivity through the thickness of the crust. We also demonstrated that EBSD and CVA analyses are essential precursor analyses for petrochronology to properly date and correlate shear zone fabric development with tectonic events. We focused our work on the largest crustal-scale shear zones exposed in Fiordland: the magma-rich George Sound Shear Zone and the magma-poor Grebe Shear Zone. In the George Sound Shear Zone, EBSD and CVA-coupled petrochronology uniquely revealed the preservation of a cryptic, regional Carboniferous transtensional tectonic event that was only partially overprinted by a Cretaceous transpressional event during shear zone reactivation and arc magmatism. This observation demonstrated that an older crustal discontinuity controlled the location of both the Carboniferous and Cretaceous shear zones, and that it channeled Cretaceous arc magma into the base of the George Sound Shear Zone at the peak of an arc magma flare-up, leading to the upward growth of the shear zone over time. In the Grebe Shear Zone, EBSD and CVA analysis revealed a more complete overprinting of older Carboniferous fabrics by Cretaceous shear zone fabrics owing to the smaller volume of Carboniferous rocks within the narrower Cretaceous Grebe Shear Zone. The Grebe Shear Zone initiated before the Cretaceous arc-flare up, and propagated downward through the crust, reactivating an old crustal and isotopic boundary in the crust. The publications resulting from this work are novel and impactful in that they were the first studies to incorporate both EBSD and CVA analysis to inform the results of petrochronology. We also established that current practices of using EBSD in petrochronology (single grain EBSD maps taken out of context with the surrounding fabric) can be insufficient to uniquely tie petrochronology dates to specific fabric elements, which is the entire premise of high-temperature petrochronology.

The primary outcome of our work with respect to broader impacts is the large number of students who benefited from the opportunities for research training, mentoring, and professional development, and the degree to which the project furthered the participation of historically excluded and underrepresented groups in the geosciences. The project supported a collaboration between three geoscientists at MS-granting institutions: PI Miranda (Hispanic female), non-PI collaborator Schwartz, both at California State University Northridge, a federally-designated Hispanic Serving Institution (HSI), and PI Klepeis, who is a researcher at the University of Vermont, an EPSCOR state. A total of 11 MS students (7 CSUN, 4 UV MS theses) and 2 undergraduate students (UV) were supported on this project, and the CSUN students recruited for this project are diverse in that nearly all are non-traditional age, first-generation, or from underrepresented or historically excluded populations in the geosciences. In addition, the project provided EBSD research training for external students through a series of workshops hosted at CSUN; most participants were from regional HSIs and/or were themselves from underrepresented populations in the geosciences. The success of this project shows the tremendous value of human resources at MS-granting and minority serving institutions; high-profile, international, and cutting-edge science and the training and career opportunities are not strictly the territory of Ph.D.-granting institutions, and the success of this project is a tangible, measurable way in which federal tax funds are used to invest in accessibility and opportunities for a diverse STEM workforce.
